body: Not all loader support resolving, please create minimum reproducible test repo, thanks
@Airkro What you expected? Why you add this stuff to `module.rules`?

After the release of webpack 4.0, I found this feature in the [changelog](https://github.com/webpack/webpack/releases/tag/v4.0.0) (although it was not found in the documentation).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12206891/55045389-95246a00-5078-11e9-9a84-fb5633460147.png)

I decided to use it because it can be used in conjunction with the `include` option to act on a limited range of code. (Guessing is helpful for speed and security).

For example, many projects use `alias: @ -> path/to/src` . But obviously it doesn't have to work on the code inside `node_modules`.

@Airkro I can't understand you, if you use `loader` and want change `resolve` use `resolve` option for `modules.rules`, if you want change global resolving change this in upper `resolver` option (not in loader), i strongly recommend don't use `@` - it is can be part of import like `import '@myorg/package'`
@Airkro please provide full reproducible test repo and describe what you have and what you expected

Many people use `alias:@`, and they don't want to change that. You can see it in `vue-cli@2.x`.
<https://github.com/vuejs-templates/webpack/blob/develop/template/build/webpack.base.conf.js#L40>

Even if I don't use it, it may be other words, it's just an example.

test repo has been updated: https://github.com/Airkro/webpack-resolve-problem

### Q&A

Q: Why do I use the `resolve.alias` option in `modules.rules[]` ?

A: I learned that it is available. So use it with the `include` option to limit its scope.

### Current behaviour

`config.modules.rules[].resolve.alias` is working but `config.resolve.alias` not work any more.

### What I expected

- `config.resolve.alias`
- `config.modules.rules[].resolve.alias`

`webpack` should auto merge them, make them work together?

@Airkro without `loader` using `config.modules.rules[].resolve` ~~doesn't has~~ should not has sense and should not merged. What do you want to do? It is really weird. 

I think we should throw schema error on this case.

Since you said so, I won't use it without loader anymore.

Even if `loader` is added, it is still not as expected.

example: [[Branch: with-loader]](https://github.com/Airkro/webpack-resolve-problem/tree/with-loader)
Yep, looks like a bug, feel free to send a PR

Yep, many this behavior is a bit weird. Changing this makes sense, but as it's a breaking change we can only do it for the next major.

As workaround copy the alias configuration to the rule, or merge it in config.

issue.title: improve merging of resolve and parsing options

repository.name: webpack
repository.description: A bundler for javascript and friends. Packs many modules into a few bundled assets. Code Splitting allows for loading parts of the application on demand. Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.

issue.body:
<!-- Thanks for submitting a pull request! Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request. -->
<!-- Explain the **motivation** for making this change. What existing problem does the pull request solve? -->
<!-- Try to link to an open issue for more information. -->

improve merging of resolve and parsing options
by rules and via loader API

Objects are deeply merged
Arrays overwrite by default, but can reference old value with "..."

fixes #8968

<!-- In addition to that please answer these questions: -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?**
feature, maybe bugfix
<!-- E.g. a bugfix, feature, refactoring, build related change, etc -->

**Did you add tests for your changes?**
yes
<!-- Note that we won't merge your changes if you don't add tests -->

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?**
yes
<!-- If this PR introduces a breaking change, please describe the impact and a migration path for existing applications. -->

**What needs to be documented once your changes are merged?**
Rule.resolve/Rule.parser objects are now deeply merged.
In array the special `"..."` item can now be used to reference to old value, while otherwise array values overwrite each other.
This also affects the `getResolve(options)` API in the loader API
<!-- List all the information that needs to be added to the documentation after merge -->
<!-- When your changes are merged you will be asked to contribute this to the documentation -->
